titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Cuyler family papers 1977.436
titlestmt.author: Matthew Gorham
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-11-29 15:31:18 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: The Cuyler family papers span the period 1720 to 1805 and measure 0.1 linear feet. The papers include miscellaneous legal documents and a land deed pertaining to the Cuyler family of Albany, New York.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. The papers were formally accessioned in 1977.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This small collection is housed in a single oversize folder with no particular arrangement.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Cuyler family papers, 1977.436, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: In November 2023, the James Abeel account sheet (1977.444) was added to this collection since that document also lists members of the Cuyler family. At that time, the collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Cuyler family papers span the period 1720 to 1805. The papers include miscellaneous legal documents and a land deed pertaining to the Cuyler family of Albany, New York.
The collection also includes an account sheet that documents goods purchased, spanning the period 1766 to 1767. James Abeel (1733-1825) was born and raised in New York City.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials in this collection are in the public domain. While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
